Incredibly thorough and spot-on comparison‚Å∞ between @aws vs @vercel, from the experience of migrating a production application already in @aws, managed by experts.

While it's obviously nice to win on these comparisons, my absolute favorite part is its conclusion:

> Ultimately, after doing a few tests to derisk we moved our entire application to Vercel over one weekend and deleted a lot of excess code. When we look at our repo now its 99% our application and 1% infrastructure. That makes us happy.

This is the power of Framework-defined Infrastructure (FdI)¬π. The "mistake" the clouds made is that their entrypoint to building became‚Ä¶ their infrastructure.

For @vercel, it's frameworks. SvelteKit, Nitro, Next.js get converted into infrastructure on the fly. 

It's fashionable for vendors to throw the term "lock-in" around, but there's actually an exact way of measuring this. You don't need to take my word for it. Count how many times you "import" or reference runtime APIs that are cloud-vendor-specific in your code (e.g.: Magic Objects, magic "env.*", magic "bindings", etc.) If you stick to framework code, then you can move the workload around, hence the '1%' above being so satisfying.

Last, of course we're proud to build on top of the @aws foundations. EC2, S3, and its global network are second-to-none. Outages are basically inexistent. "POP re-routing" is not a thing. There's no "low-tier network", just the best private fiber network, 24x7x365.

Our commitment to our customers & community is to continue to build Open SDKs¬≤, and create the best possible autonomous cloud for them, atop the highest performance 'hardware' we can find.

Most caching systems have a ‚Äúcold start‚Äù problem where if they haven‚Äôt seen the path before, and therefore not had a Cache-Control response yet, they can‚Äôt shield.

This system does not, out of the box, with zero configuration.

I‚Äôm sure you can VCL spaghetti your way there, but you lose local DX and now application developers can‚Äôt ship good outcomes

It's now well understood that the better the context, the better the performance of AI models.

But it's the same lesson as scaling human organizations. Maximize and enrich context. Engineers and designers are not code & pixels pushers. They solve business problems.

At Vercel we've found that maximizing transparency and a 'build in public' ethos increases autonomy (agency üòÅ) and makes work more fulfilling and impactful.

@schniz You know what you can ship to turn this around üòè

I re-interview our best performers. 

I set time aside to understand why they ramp faster, ship faster, understand customers better.

Recently I got one of the best compliments about our organization. This engineer came from a really good startup. He joined when they were 20 people and left when they were 50.

But he said that at Vercel, despite being over 10x the size, *he can ship faster than at the smaller startup*. Better infrastructure (dogfooding @vercel) and less bureaucracy, especially around picking up projects and marketing your work.

I think this should be the norm moving forward. Companies can only grow headcount proportional to provable velocity increase. Big companies that move slow are not good for the world.

No need for `cache-control`. In fact you'll notice we send aggressive "don't cache" to clients. Because we want you to have full control of the cache lifecycle on the cloud side.

Cache-control is full of footguns like stampedes / calling origin too frequently on MISS, etc. CF and others paper it over with lots of enterprise proprietary SKUs you have to pile on to make it half-work. Truth nuke.

Vercel Fluid vs Cloudflare Workers.

üí¨"From my findings, Vercel is 1.2x to 5x faster than CloudFlare for server rendering."

We gave a very, very earnest try to Workers when we explored the edge runtime / world. There's no "beef", we had to migrate off for technical reasons.

To be fair to them, they brought new ideas to the market. The CPU-based pricing for instance was good and Vercel Fluid has it as well.

The main issues we ran into:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Bad CPU performance, low capacity, very irregular and spiky latency. The benchmarks show you this.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Single-vendor runtime. You can't run "Node.js 24". You run "whatever they give you, which is trying to look like Node.js but it's not"
3Ô∏è‚É£ Really bad connectivity to the clouds. We measured the roundtrip time between AWS and CF Workers as being in the low 10s to 100s of milliseconds

The result of us migrating off was shipping Fluid. You pay for CPU, it handles concurrency like a server (cost-efficient), you control the size / memory of the functions, you get full, open runtimes like @nodejs and Python, you get 1ms latency to cloud services‚Ä¶

Most people today are using Fluid and they don't even notice, because it just works¬Æ with the entire ecosystem.

Here are the benchmarks @theo ran: https://t.co/JNFJWmsWZJ

A lot of younger people who‚Äôre new to the industry ask me how to do ‚Äúnetworking‚Äù. 

How do you go from knowing no one in San Francisco to having a network of people that you can do business with, learn from, hire, etc.

The trick is I never set out to ‚Äúnetwork‚Äù. Maybe due to Tylenol exposure in womb, or just pure intuition, but I could never fathom that I‚Äôd go to an event or reach out to someone to ‚Äúnetwork‚Äù. ‚ÄúHi this is G and I‚Äôm here to network‚Äù.

Instead what I focused on was creating value for others and focus on positive value exchanges. Creating open source projects is the ‚Äúhyper scale‚Äù version of this. You‚Äôre networking with the world, but you‚Äôre doing so by leading with value and with content. Writing essays, teaching people things, giving lightning talks, vibe coding an experiment, all more valuable.

What you‚Äôre going to notice is that networks build around value, not the other way around.

Even today, whenever I reach out to someone, I try to lead with some insight, datapoint, maybe a bug report or suggestion for their product‚Ä¶ something tangible. If they have a product or platform with APIs, I start by networking *our systems*.

I‚Äôve made amazing, close connections to people who I frequently chat with and I‚Äôve never met IRL. I also make it a point to talk to everybody. Anons, interns, juniors, seniors, CEOs, board members, trolls.

tl;DR: Focus on creating value, think long term, don‚Äôt be transactional.

Some facts. The visa that‚Äôs been fueling Silicon Valley is O-1, not H-1B. It‚Äôs called ‚ÄúIndividual of Extraordinary Ability‚Äù. It costs about $1000 to apply¬π and it‚Äôs unchanged.

But what it also costs is the burden of proof of contribution. It‚Äôs the visa I got as an Argentinian national. And it put me through the wringer.

As evidence to obtain it, I submitted being a Wiley-published book author, press coverage, letters of recommendation from leaders of the field, commanding a high salary, participation in industry associations and events, the impact of my open source contributions, and more.

This country is so great and so worth fighting for, that I put an immense amount of work into my application.

I believe any reward as appealing and compelling as getting to move to the USA is bound to face widespread abuse. The best possible immigration policy will balance keeping the bar really high, ensuring people who love this country, culture, and values, and are willing to work hard get their shot at the American Dream, but never doing so at the expense of those already here.

True. Some of the most educational experiences of my life:

‚ñ™Ô∏è Built lots of little web frameworks and ORMs in PHP. I‚Äôd set up constraints like ‚Äúhas to be a single file‚Äù or experimenting with new syntax or language features.

‚ñ™Ô∏è Built my own container engine and K8S-style orchestrator. Learning about Linux namespaces, seccomp, networking, squashfs was amazing. I also paradoxically developed massive respect for K8S even though I don‚Äôt want to use it. Creating a system that can schedule and run so many ‚Äúkinds‚Äù of things, in such disparate environments, is mind-bogglingly difficult.

‚ñ™Ô∏è I rolled my own React. My own VDOM diffing algorithm, functional syntax, reactive values, etc. There were aspects of my design that could have been ‚Äúbetter‚Äù but I realized React would continue to evolve and win. I learned that a growing ecosystem consensus has as much ‚Äútechnical‚Äù merit as performance or API shapes.

If you‚Äôre an engineer or engineer-in-the-making, there‚Äôs never been a better time to reinvent the wheel. Get busy vibe-re-implementing things and you‚Äôll learn a lot.

Turso is an incredible technical feat. A Rust rewrite of sqlite, with an async-first architecture, incoming support for concurrent writes, vector search, and browser / wasm support out of the box.

I think this has a very good chance of being a foundational piece of infrastructure of the vibe-coding age. On-demand, sqlite-compatible global databases that can also run in-browser and on-device.

The pace at which the project is evolving is most definitely *not normal*. @penberg and @glcst are built different.

Customer removed a proxy in front of @vercel and saw a 50% reduction in TTFB. What's cool about this view is that it's Speed Insights, which grabs data from end users devices. It's as close as you can get to the truth.

Generally speaking, developers get too caught up on "how it feels on my machine" or "I saw some random benchmark on the internet".

I encourage you to always look at the field data to draw conclusions. Hence why this is called "RUM" (Real User Monitoring). Any RUM tool should work (@getsentry, @datadoghq, etc).

[4/4] Our support team is absolutely cracked, and I'm extremely thankful for their dedication to our customers. So I spent quite a bit of time to debugging how we can make our own support experience better with AI.

Even though we already answer tickets with AI, and even though we already have a 'AI support assistant' for the behind-the-scenes, there's still huge amounts of alpha.

Some takeaways:

‚ñ™Ô∏è A lot of the support AI tools were conceived as one-shot assistants. What we've learned with @v0 is that there's a 100x upside in upgrading from "models" to "agents".

‚ñ™Ô∏è We're working on content drafting agents that allow us to take common patterns and best practices and create durable content from them. Great opportunity for dogfooding our AI Cloud capabilities.

‚ñ™Ô∏è Support Engineers are absolutely crucial and AI is not replacing them anytime soon üòä AI is getting rid of the uninteresting tickets. The ones that remain require significant effort and creativity to tackle, and, crucially, inform product roadmap and decisions. 

I expect AI to continue to have an enormous impact here though. We're not nearly 10% done accelerating delivering quality help to users, and there's a lot more we can do to help them help themselves.

[3/4] A customer was having issues understanding the lifecycle of Image Optimization.

They updated an image on their DAM (place where they host images), but the optimized cache copy was not reflecting a change.

This uncovered a few issues:
‚ñ™Ô∏è The TTL behavior is hard to understand. We respect ùô≤ùöäùöåùöëùöé-ùô≤ùöòùöóùöùùöõùöòùöï, but there's also a ùöñùöíùöóùöíùöñùöûùöñùô≤ùöäùöåùöëùöéùöÉùöÉùôª param. It's hard to understand this and we could do better docs and observability wise
‚ñ™Ô∏è DAMs should be able to trigger a preemptive revalidation of our cache. Customers should not have to wait. We're working on the CDN APIs to tell Vercel "recompute this value in the background, and only replace the cache if it works and is error-free". This is basically what Next.js ISR does and it's a Godsend, but we're going to give you platform APIs for it.

One of the common reminders I get when operating at Vercel scale is that there's no such thing as too much observability. There's endless appetite for more logs, more traces, more ways to inspect the behind the scenes of the machine.

[2/4] A customer from a large consulting group was having issues with the deployment pipeline. It was a high priority ticket due to the SLA we honor and criticality of the project.

It was a very unusual edge case related to exceeding function size from a large dependency. The "build" phase was fine, but the "deploy" phase was not. I recommended two things:

‚ñ™Ô∏èLittle known fact. Vercel CLI has a command called ùöüùöéùöõùöåùöéùöï ùöãùöíùöúùöéùöåùöù that performs a binary search so that you can try out Deployment URLs and find the one that introduced the regression. It's a life-saver

‚ñ™Ô∏èTry to identify accidental importing of large deps, look at the output of ùöüùöéùöõùöåùöéùöï ùöãùöûùöíùöïùöç, and use the bundle analysis tools in Next.js 

Overall, the big takeaway here is that we have an opportunity to do better in the logs view and help you explore the inputs and outputs better.

We're also working on Vercel Agent automatically helping diagnose issues and open PRs, which should help in the future.

[1/4] A customer wanted a 'vibe check' on how to implement an Age Gate that preserved SEO. i.e.: normal users get presented with the Age Gate, but Google goes through.

When they implemented it naively, their SEO tanked. I went to @v0 and ended up creating a demo on how to implement this with Middleware that I've now contributed to Community.

You can see it here: https://t.co/lsk79ehhe3 (press 'Built in v0' to access the template).

(Note: while 'cloaking' is usually frowned upon, Google makes exceptions for age gating for legal reasons: https://t.co/rT0W6flbx3)

The amount of code being written is growing exponentially. Reviewing is the new bottleneck, not coding.

Vercel Agent captures the ideal workflow you'd hope a peer programmer with infinite energy would perform for every pull request:

‚ñ™Ô∏è It clones, installs deps, type checks, lints your code
‚ñ™Ô∏è It's an expert in your tech stack
‚ñ™Ô∏è It has a great signal : noise ratio 
‚ñ™Ô∏è It comments but also applies fixes to the PR
‚ñ™Ô∏è It thinks 'adversarially'. Its goal is to vibe check

People who've tried it consistently tell us it's hard to imagine going back to a world without it.

In our tests, it's captured security vulnerabilities, it's prevented outages, and made significant performance improvements. It's spotted edge cases that expert engineers fail to identify.

There‚Äôre two broad categories of AI workloads we‚Äôre seeing on @vercel:

1Ô∏è‚É£ AaaS: agent-as-a-service 
2Ô∏è‚É£ DIY agents

Most of the successful, sticky Enterprise adoption today is in ‚ë†: procuring AaaS.

This is why ChatGPT Enterprise is ripping and why @v0 is virally spreading in the Fortune 500. It‚Äôs doing so at a speed we‚Äôve never seen in cloud infra products. @chatbase is another cool example of a high growth startup with an extremely simple adoption model.

DIY agents today are more reliant on the forward-deployed engineer model. It‚Äôs hard for Enterprise companies to go from 0 to 1 on agents on such a fast moving space.

This is what we want to unlock with @aisdk and the @vercel AI Cloud. The cloud won in the first place because companies have very business-specific problems. They need to build custom agents as well as agent platforms. We‚Äôll make this extremely easy to do. We‚Äôre building the cloud services of this new generation (CDN of AI: AI Gateway, Lambda of AI: Fluid, EC2 of AI: Sandbox‚Ä¶).

This is not a serverless horror. This is what happens when you‚Äôre on a metered resources plan. Like Argo, or Hetzner once you go over 1/TB in the US.

The solution is not to tell people that limited resources are unlimited. In fact, when you do that, you just created the next botnet. Or FUD.

Our solution is to invest in security by default (Firewall on by default), anomaly alerting, caps, and common sense policies and customer support practices.

This is a very strong argument *for* @vercel that I strongly agree with. When we tried the edge worker thing, we were seeing 10ms hops between edge and aws region. It was devastating.

Vercel Fluid functions run inside the same AZs and regions as most databases and services in the world.

So, Supabase and Vercel are actually usually <1ms away. They're not in the same physical machine, but I think you'll learn very quickly that's not the great idea you think it is. Networks inside AZs are majestically fast.

Notice I said "services". This also means Vercel is in the same datacenters as most of the cloud services in the world, like Stripe. This is how we run some of the largest stores on the planet, that trust us for their rendering and CDN, and use backends like Salesforce Commerce Cloud.

(We have a product called Secure Compute that actually binds VPCs together inside AWS that's really popular for these use cases)

I just deployed a Nitro project in 10s to Production on the Hobby tier.

The target is the "drag and drop to FTP" experience, and I believe we can do better than 5s actually üòÅ, with the advent of incremental compilers like Turbopack & Vite.

But it's worth pointing out what the cloud has gotten us in the meantime.

When I was FTPing PHP files, I had no recourse if something went wrong. Rolling back required manually reverting every mutation to every file.

Thus we invented the concept of "deployment images". The most popular imaging format today is Docker. When you deploy to Vercel, we create an immutable snapshot of every deployment, including static assets, CDN configuration, routing logic, and crucially, the core application server functions.

On Vercel, this gets you a couple things. One thing that people love is "Instant Rollback". We can atomically revert a mistake with a single click, including purging the global CDN caches and updating the config.

Another amazing one, pioneered by DHH's arch-nemesis AWS, is multi-AZ redundancy. It's quite amazing to me that even on the free tier of Vercel, you get not just an insanely high level of network redundancy, but also compute redundancy. You can tolerate entire buildings of a datacenter 'catching fire'.

Because the cloud today runs some of the most mission-critical services on the planet, you can go further. We can deploy these "deployment snapshots" across multiple regions, and fail over automatically. That means not just buildings can go offline, an entire city could go offline and your application would work.

As a fun fact, I share the dream of the immediacy of syncing a file (or maybe even a line of code), and seeing it online. It was one of the major inspirations for starting @vercel. 

There're a few things I can't concede though. 

For example, back then PHP would run as an interpreter, which means that after you sync the file, the speed at which it can be executed was quite limiting, giving a bad experience to end users.

They later introduced an "OPcache" which speeds up the interpreter by optimizing certain codepaths into machine code. 

To us, it's kind of unacceptable that an end-user would have to pay the "tax" of triggering the optimization of your code. That's why we build and optimize your code as part of those 10s (as an aside, it's kinda funny that in his meme the bar is "5s" for not doing this :P).

DHH has been vocally against builds with his "nobuild" movement. This is one of the most incomprehensible and inadmissible parts of his rhetoric. As developers, we're supposed to hurt the user experience for our pleasure. But it's a false dichotomy. We can and will have the cake and eat it too. Compilers are awesome, actually, and the foundation of all engineering.

I'm excited about how awesome the JS and TS ecosystem is getting. Nitro is becoming the foundation for open and vendor-agnostic deployment, and it's lean and snappy. The tooling (thanks Rust!) is getting blazing fast. And libraries like React, Vue and Svelte are becoming very mature and easier to use.

We‚Äôve engineered Vercel so that live deployments are unaffected by any gap of availability or performance of our core databases.

How? We employ a multi-tiered caching architecture and a global metadata replication system.

But: what if the database or core region that manages deployments, rollbacks, new projects went fully down? What if our core region suffered from a natural disaster?

At the limit, not being able to revert a bad deployment can be just as damaging as dropping live CDN traffic on the workload.

We ran a successful simulation of this disaster scenario and wrote up on it ‚Üì

Whenever you wonder how big the gap between "what AI can theoretically do" vs "how much AI is applied today" is, look no further than Gmail's spam filters.

Multiple times a week, I get a fake notice that my X account has been logged-in from somewhere trying to scam me out of my password and 2FA token. Right into my main inbox. Served in a Gmail app notification platter.

The URL then redirects to ùöëùöéùöïùöô.ùöúùöûùöúùöôùöíùöåùöíùöòùöûùöú-ùöäùöåùöåùöòùöûùöóùöù-ùö°.ùöåùöòùöñ. Most of the emails I've been getting also exploit some kind of URL redirect service, most recently ùöùùöõ.ùöúùöûùöõùöüùöéùö¢ùöñùöòùöóùöîùöéùö¢.ùöåùöòùöñ or ùöúùöåùöäùöóùöóùöéùöç.ùöôùöäùöêùöé, a QR code generator service.

Models are like EC2. If your entire product is to re-expose EC2 as-is, you'll likely be in a tough business.

But: if you write software on top of EC2, now you're part of the cloud economy. As an analogy, if we go by the @redpoint's InfraRed Cloud Infrastructure index, $600B+ of public company value has been created on top of cloud primitives by 23 cloud companies¬π

And that's just public companies, only a fragment of the entire cloud value chain.

I believe the AI cloud economy is going to be much larger. The model is a very important base layer, but there's an immense amount of value to be added on top to ship great products. (In fact, if anything, we've seen that the model layer is fluid and uncertain, having changed or upgraded models probably a dozen times at @v0).

People will want to buy AI applications and agents that solve useful, concrete and domain-specific problems. That are secure, reliable, have a high quality bar, mitigate errors and minimize slop. Models alone are not enough.

Yesterday at @vercel we took an important step towards enabling this future with a foundational piece of our AI Cloud platform: the AI Gateway. It's never been easier to access these new foundations. With a few lines of @aisdk code + a single API key, you get zero-markup, virtually unlimited access to 100+ models. 

The best part: we're partnering with the best labs and inference providers in the world to give you day0 access to new models and increasingly affordable and faster tokens.

We're cooking on more services that integrate seamlessly and lower the barrier to entry and raise the security bar of AI, like Sandbox and BotID. Join us in building the AI Cloud ü´°

We've been building an AI coding agent optimized for Vercel and web technologies. 

It's extremely exciting. At one point we accidentally disabled it on one of our core repos and our devs almost went on strike üòÇ

We've been, however, unusually‚Ä¶ "slow" in its rollout process. Why? Security.

Over the past few weeks and months, we've now seen agents and MCP servers succumb to several disastrous security vulnerabilities. File a public GitHub issue and their MCP server will leak private repos. File a JIRA ticket and you'll hijack a developer's machine. Etc.

As far as the solution goes, the good ol' principles of security apply: principle of least privilege, not trusting user inputs (injections), and isolation.

Much of the AI ecosystem has perplexingly evolved around local data and local compute. Local MCP servers. Agents with full access to your *entire machine*. Like, Claude Code runs commands in the same computer and filesystem namespace that has your selfies' albums. 1) What. (Incidentally it's why right now the tech is so annoying to use, with disclaimers, warnings and interruptions everywhere.)

One of the primitives we introduced as part of our AI Cloud is the Vercel Sandbox (https://t.co/KfL3upDdzj). We're extremely excited about this. It's basically an "ephemeral personal computer for agents". You, as a developer, can strictly control what gets into it. For instance, what repos the agent gets access to, or what tools. It builds on a decade of lessons on securing Vercel's build machines, which start instantly, scale to millions of instances per day, and get destroyed after each use¬≤.

We can't wait to share it with you very soon, as well as more of the lessons we're learning along the way¬≥

Some early & evolving thoughts on "agentic DX":

1Ô∏è‚É£ More 'hyperlocal reasoning' APIs (like Tailwind)
i.e.: APIs that rely less on 'reading in more context' in order to be interpreted.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Less pressure on verbosity. 
While humans' fingers get tired when typing, LLMs emitting tokens do not. APIs like `ùöçùöäùöóùöêùöéùöõùöòùöûùöúùöïùö¢ùöÇùöéùöùùô∏ùöóùöóùöéùöõùô∑ùöÉùôºùôª` are good, actually. Explicit, convey semantics, etc. This is also true for logging verbosity, stack traces, etc.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Double down on the filesystem 
Claude Code-like agents are reinforced on filesystem operations. They like to `ls`, `find`, `cat`, `head`. Filesystem route organization in @nextjs App Router naturally 'sections off' parts of the application that can get their own specific agent instructions. 

4Ô∏è‚É£ CLI ergonomics
CLIs generally need to provide better feedback, have non-interactive modes, and centralize output. An example here is @nextjs forwarding browser logs (currently under a flag) so that agents can have a 'single pane of glass' of debugging info:

Overall, there's a lot of overlap between "good DX" and "good agent DX". I think of making things better for agents as an optimization. If the foundations are not solid, no amount of AI will fix them.

For users, this is the ideal experience. I use Grok myself like this every day. I don't want 10 blue links and a bunch of browser tabs. I want the AI to do the research for me.

For companies, this is the future of getting information out about your products. It's going to be the norm and it'll be bigger than social media. Instead of blocking AI with legacy firewalls, I'd focus on:

‚ñ™Ô∏è writing content that matches the kinds of questions people are asking about
‚ñ™Ô∏è massively speeding up your content velocity. So many nuggets of wisdom get lost in private channels and groups. Get information out more quickly!

I've been testing out the upcoming @v0 agent release and‚Ä¶ I've never had so much fun üòÅ

Using a @sketchfab 3d model, I was able to guide v0 to do a pretty good rendition of Stripe Press, one of the coolest sites on the internet.

One of the things you'll notice this week is that you can be much more ambitious & 'full stack' with the things you ask v0‚Ä¶ it makes *a lot* fewer mistakes. Just like any AI, it won't perfectly nail everything and you'll have to provide feedback, but at no point did it get stuck in a *programming* sense.

It had to do some pretty hard things to render this book. For instance, the Sketchfab model didn't have "UV mappings", which as I've learned, is the geometry that describes the 'target' of a texture. I generated the textures using AI itself (FLUX by @bfl_ml is quite insane). Then v0 had to do a lot of tricky math to decide which parts of the geometry constitute the "front" of the book and the "back" of the book.

I got to learn a lot from building this even though I actually didn't write a single line of code, which is a testament IMO to the power vibe coding gives you. I  think we'll see a lot more 'custom' experiences on the web in the coming years, from ecommerce to content, using 3D (threejs), generative video & images, and 3d worlds.

Software 1.0 (SaaS) was a rigid, static form of intelligence. 

Some smart, highly motivated group of software-savvy humans get together, try to spot patterns and workflows in a given domain, smash some Red Bulls, stand up a database, wrap some UI around it, bundle it into a binary, and hit publish.

Buyers are happy they‚Äôre finally understood and cared for by a software vendor. ‚ÄúThis company Boopitify from Palo Alto finally cracked the problem!‚Äù

As the product and market matures, more customers join the platform, the initial simplicity erodes little by little. The platform slows down by the endless stream of features, bug fixes, dialogs with nested dialogs, integrations, permission systems, Enterprise‚Ñ¢Ô∏è requirements. The platform eventually gets so generic, it gets dumber, and it makes you, the user, feel dumb and disempowered.

AI cuts right to the chase. You‚Äôre no longer buying a rigid proxy for intelligence. You‚Äôre buying ingelligence itself, measured in tokens. This is, incidentally, the same the cloud did for infrastructure. No more rigid, static, fixed-size data center. Everything is consumed on-demand, and it‚Äôs on tap.

The key enabler of this has been code generation. Whether it‚Äôs vibe coding, GenUI, or agents, the software we used to code, is now generated. The interfaces we used to design: generated. The prototypes we used to spec: generated.

For vendors, it means rethinking your interfaces. Agents or assistants rather than rigid UIs. MCPs rather than rigid integrations.

For AI labs, it means winning the coding war. Agents need to write and execute their own code to solve problems. 

For infra providers, it means rethinking what the ‚Äúhello world‚Äù app is. It‚Äôs increasingly not web services. This is why we‚Äôre building the AI Cloud, made up of AI services, for AI apps, orchestrated by AI agents.

tl;DR: this paper is really impressive. I'd say Curtis anticipated 95% of React. It also anticipated and really well articulated the pitfalls of its imperative competitors.

The other 5%, however, is arguably what made React win among many other "similar enough" things that came before it. 

Had the author not detoured into XML markup extensions, and focused on the fact that ∆í(x) would be a user-defined, ECMAScript, `ùöõùöéùöóùöçùöéùöõ()` function, this paper would be an all-timer.

The last part of the paper discusses the "WAX" XML language. This is I think where the paper goes astray and commits its major mistake.

It explicitly calls out that dynamism *requires* a extension to the markup language. 

This is the mistake that many predecessors of React made. In addition to ùöè(ùöúùöùùöäùöùùöé) ‚Üí ùöüùöíùöéùö†, one of the early React-isms was that "it was just JavaScript". While originally it looked "odd" to people that React had put "tags" in JS, it turned out to be right.

Reacts's authors decided that they would not have you learn new extensions to html like `ùöü:ùöíùöè`.

Putting tags in JS won over putting JS in tags¬≤

¬≤ which Curtis suggests in [0085]

We're later significantly back. The author here talks about incremental updates and foreshadows memoization.

The "semi-automatic case" can be mapped to `ùöúùöëùöòùöûùöïùöçùô≤ùöòùöñùöôùöòùöóùöéùöóùöùùöÑùöôùöçùöäùöùùöé()` and `ùöûùöúùöéùôºùöéùöñùöò()`, and the optimization for the automatic case React Compilers (or even Signals!)

It's briefly so over. The author confirms the orange flag from the abstract. 

The transformation function between local data set and presentation is not an actual user-specified function, vis-a-vis, React's famous `ùöõùöéùöóùöçùöéùöõ()` function. It's‚Ä¶

In 2015, I wrote a popular essay called "Pure UI" that synthesizes this idea and speaks to the programming-design convergence we're seeing today:

Reading further, we continue to be back. For 2000, this is a near perfect foreshadowing of the subsequent 10-ish years of DOM updading hell.

‚ñ™Ô∏èDOM mutations become very hard to reason about ("authoring difficult"), especially as projects / teams grow 
‚ñ™Ô∏èAn event you don't handle that "self-modifies" the DOM without your intervention (i.e.: updating the "local Data Set") is the crux of the matter indeed.

The automatic update aspect foreshadows that you should not be manipulating the output DOM. You should be manipulating state, and let React reconcile automatically (State ‚Üí Virtual DOM ‚Üí DOM transformation).

It was potentially so over, but we're so back quickly when we get to the Figures enumeration. 

Fig 5 in particular foreshadows not just React quite well, but also its algebraic denotation. 

In the early days of React, one of the key insights was that jQuery was "wrong" because it consisted of a series of imperative ad-hoc transformations on the output markup.

React popularized the idea that:
ùöè(ùô≥ùöäùöùùöä ùöÇùöéùöù¬π) ‚Üí ùôøùöõùöéùöúùöéùöóùöùùöäùöùùöíùöòùöó

Orange flag here: "source document written in extensible markup language"

I love thinking about 'surprisingly large datasets'. For one thing, I doubt the Slack devs knew how many custom emojis I alone would upload, let alone our entire org.

And then there must be a Slack org out there with millions of custom emojis. A version at Vercel of this is deployments. We first imagined it'd roughly map to number of commits per day. Then we started seeing platforms make hundreds of thousands of deployments per day, on behalf of other users.

Another version of this is our CDN routing table. How many routes do you think an application can have? Well, think bigger. Some customers have tens of millions of redirects alone.

A fun example is that in 2009, the "Twitpocalypse" almost happened. Twitter didn't expect that there'd eventually be 2,147,483,647 tweet IDs[1], the largest representable value of a 32-bit signed integer.

Today, X likely does that entire number in a weekend.

It's hard to anticipate how big things get or how they'll be used in the wild, so you shouldn't overthink this. However, these migrations can be quite painful. You might think as an engineer "custom emojis will be a JSONB column in this row". Well, no, they'll eventually be a custom table with 500 trillion rows. And then you'll have to do work that'll mostly be invisible to your users, but is essential to continue scaling.

This is why serious infrastructure systems scale with well-defined limits. For example, AWS DynamoDB has a max document / item size of 400kb. Sometimes it's frustrating to hear that things have limits, but then you grow to realize you *want* the limits and respect those systems more. I suspect that as more of documentation gets precisely derived from code, the last 'kind' of human-specified documentation will likely be the systems semantics that don't map neatly to code, like quotas and such.

Yeah TBH I considered it a mis-feature after my testing. I don't want to sound critical of Lambda bc I actually embraced it once I realized people hate the 'overloaded, under-scaled server' problem as much as they hate the cold start.

In fact, the queueing of your request in a saturated event loop server is effectively a cold start üòÇ the user stares at a blank, hanging page. Just different root causes, but latency nonetheless.

After 2 years of iteration at scale, here's everything we learned about engineering Fluid.

The most desirable (yet seemingly hardest to attain) property of a compute system is *efficient and predictable performance at any scale*.

Serverless as pioneered by Lambda had an unusual set of tradeoffs. It has the potential for cold starts in production, which is a no-go.

What's lesser known though is that it solved for the achilles heel of servers: noisy neighbors, congestion, and inadequate load balancing. 

It did so at tremendous expense (1 "computer" per concurrent request), but it was glorious. I sometimes compare this to you and your friend leave work to go to the same exact restaurant, at the same time, but you both order Uber XLs. You'll have an amazing experience, but it's wasteful.

When we built Fluid, we wanted to have the cake and eat it too. I'm particularly happy with our algorithm that uses 'every available seat in the car' (great for AI apps that wait a lot on tokens), but spins up more computers horizontally as needed. This is something exceedingly hard to get right, even for experienced DevOps teams.

üçµ On Tea Dating, AI and Vibe Coding security
TL;DR: the antidote for mistakes AIs make is‚Ä¶ more AI.

I've gotten quite a few pings on the Tea dating app security breach, that leaked 72,000 selfies, driver licenses and IDs. 

There's speculation that 'vibe coding' is the culprit, i.e., AI agents writing code for mostly non-technical users with app or business ideas. 

Given @vercel builds @v0, a platform with 7 app generations per second, and our AI cloud hosts many platforms in this category (like @cursor_ai and @durableai), I thought I'd share my thoughts on this.

First, AI coding is here to stay. Microsoft's @satyanadella reported 30% of their code is now written by AI, Google's @sundarpichai reported 25% last year, Meta aims for 50% by 2026. For younger companies like Robinhood, it's now the 'majority' of its code.

Let's now analyze the particular vulnerability at hand. From the leaks on 4chan and other sources, it sounds like the Firebase cloud storage bucket was exposed to the public. Imagine if you took your iCloud Photos and gave them to the whole internet.

Fun fact: we can actually confirm this because the Wayback Machine crawled that bucket, which is essentially like any other URL on the internet:

(source: https://t.co/SPpmuRPmuG)

So, onto vibe coding. It's true that Vibe Coding has increased the frequency of this category of incident, which we can broadly describe as "any client gets access to all the server data". 2 similar leaks came to our attention just last week, including a viral 'waitlist' app where all the emails were leaked to the client:

Lots to unpack here.

First, this category of issue is not exclusive to AI coding. The best analogy to understand what's happening to programming is self-driving cars. Autonomous vehicles operate with the same tools and platforms as humans (steering wheel, highway), much like AI coding uses existing cloud infrastructure and programming languages.

When I saw this Firebase issue, it reminded me of virtually the same thing that happened to expert human coders using Firebase not too long ago (https://t.co/kiGd1Yjbj1). Cursor, ClickUp, Linear, Notion Calendar and many other apps using ToDesktop were not just leaking 'selfies', they were leaking the entire ability to mutate and run code on your computer ü§Ø (As a citizen of the internet, I at the time loudly expressed my huge gratitude to the responsible disclosure of the researcher and the speedy response from ToDesktop.)

If we go further back in time, we see this category of issue afflicting "human drivers of code", much like both self-driving and normal cars can both crash, throughout history. The way you find this vulnerability is astonishingly easy. In the case of Tea, it took exactly all of three clicks in a web browser (‚ë† View ‚Üí ‚ë° Developer Tools ‚Üí ‚ë¢ Network) and some ingenuity.

For ToDesktop, it was basically the same, but with an extra layer of obfuscation (download the app source, de-obfuscate it, find a Firebase db admin password, now you can push any source code update to these apps).

For Capital One, the same again, but with 2 extra layers: find vulnerability in an app, then find an open 'admin server' (the EC2 metadata server), then get full access to an entire network of computers (https://t.co/297PgBzT7m).

So, it's obvious this issue was common even when programming was wielded by engineering experts, even at banks where the security bar is set really high. With AI, it's likely more code will be written in the next few months alone than in the entire history of computers.

Where do we go from here?

1Ô∏è‚É£ More AI. When we saw one of the earliest vibe coding snafus happen in our industry, the @v0 team moved quickly to deploy an agent that reviews the generated LLM code and patches it automatically. Our metrics show that we prevent thousands of these issues a week.

If these issues are easy for humans to detect, they're easy for AIs to detect too.

What's more, this technology can be leveraged for automatically reviewing code written by humans and other AIs. This is an example of a vulnerability caught by our @vercel review agent, which we'll be rolling out more broadly:

What's exciting about this is that this system learns and improves from every review and every incident for every customer, much like the entire fleet of self-driving cars learns from crashes.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Agent-native infrastructure. Why is it so easy for an agent to do the wrong thing?

If you're a developer, you know that code that deals with authorization and access to secrets does not belong client-side. It belongs server-side. It's been a well-understood programming practice for years.

And because it's been part of the programming canon, LLMs and agents know it too. Some platforms are not giving the agents the right infrastructure to work with. For example, giving agents production database access to save on storage costs, or giving them a limited runtime (running code in the browser) to save on compute costs.

With @v0, we're working very hard for this 'self-driving car' to not just meet the bar of quality of what a human expert would do, but exceed it. I believe AI will create more secure, more performant, more accessible code, but this time in the hands of everyone.

For context, I saw it on HN and noticed he had attack challenge mode on, which is an ultra aggressive form of bot management.

I DMd to suggest our Bot Protection instead, which is something we‚Äôre working hard to make a default. It filters out obvious bots, except for good, authenticated bots like stripe webhooks ü§ë automatically

One of the areas of obsession at @vercel is availability. Every. single. request. is critical. 

ISR was designed to go beyond caching, it's a durable storage system that ensures:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Global performance
2Ô∏è‚É£ Cache-stampede protection[2]

In terms of speed, ISR can apply to the entire page, or even the initial flush of the skeleton (PPR).

The backend protection side of this is more subtle. When you use hand-roll `cache-control` and you purge, you're opening up a 'hole' for a stampede or "dogpile" to crush your site's backend. ISR prevents that, because we know we can 'de-dupe' invalidations.

Our team worked really hard to design both the framework and infrastructure that prevent this, even if you're getting started.

So much so that you can delete your database and Vercel will keep you online until you recover it üëá

Barrels and ammunition ‚Üí barrels and tokens

The classic @rabois startup wisdom is that at software companies you need two kinds of people: 

‚ñ™Ô∏è barrels: rare, high-leverage individuals in a company who can take an idea from start to finish

‚ñ™Ô∏è ammunition: talented specialists (engineers, designers) who execute excellently but need direction and ownership to be effective

In the AI age all the leverage belongs to the barrels. The tools are getting so good they can now effectively take any idea to reality for the right barrel. The ammunition is LLM tokens and parallel agents.

I think this is best summary of how the software engineering market changes from now on (ht @cramforce).

Active CPU pricing on Fluid has saved us 77% on our Vercel bill.

This is the most significant infrastructure optimization we‚Äôve shipped to date. It obviously changes how much you pay, but also the entire experience of using our product.

Over the past year, our own workload mix has shifted. We‚Äôve been deploying more backends, more APIs, more full stack apps. AI calls have extended the duration of responses. 

It‚Äôs not just us. The web is undergoing a pretty dramatic shift. From pixels to tokens. From pages to agents. From HTTP to MCP. From foreground to background.

If you‚Äôre building compute infrastructure like we are, running the code is, perhaps counter intuitively, only the tip of the iceberg. I‚Äôm super proud of what we‚Äôve accomplished, with over 1 trillion invocations, multi-AZ reliability, multi-region with 1 LOC, secure VPC connectivity, ‚Ä¶

But beyond the actual compute, the product experience is actually determined by the pricing model and the observability of the system. 

Massive kudos to the compute, pricing, financial infrastructure, and observability teams at Vercel for coming together to ship a truly customer-centric experience, with built-in realtime usage understanding. 

If you haven‚Äôt enabled Fluid, it takes one click to do so. Let me know how it works for you.

@pceegalaxy With regards to file uploads, while what I recommended is the best practice, we also intend to increase the max body size for inputs. We‚Äôve made it really really easy to upload v performantly and reliably:

- We recommend uploading large files to Vercel Blob or S3. This handles multipart, resumption, maxes out upload speed through parallelism. 
- If you‚Äôre on Pro, we prevent cold starts with minimum 1 instance automatically 
- You can run for up to ~13 minutes on Pro. We just raised the defaults too

Here's why I'd study this codebase:

[1] I single out auth specifically because it's always tricky, both in implementation, but also how to insert it into the user experience correctly. The way Sahaj uses it is the best. It's very low friction, and I'm willing to log in because the product already proved its value to me.

I asked @v0 to visualize this quite literally monumental achievement by the team. 8294 tests passing.

Turns out that doing realtime physical simulation over 8294 bodies is quite performance intensive. v0 implemented the same animation in 3 different physics engines (matter-js, planck.js, rapier) effortlessly. In three shots it did what would take a human hours or days. We settled on Rapier which was the fastest.

There are many other cool details it nailed. I asked for the falling bodies to increase exponentially. It starts out with a few blocks, then more fall, then it's a torrent of blocks üòÅ

We'll be likely bumping up these numbers, so that each slice of work can get longer. But combining queues + 13 minute tasks can get you really far and help you build reliable products

Astute readers might be noticing‚Ä¶ since @vercel now has queues, higher execution times, and active cpu pricing, you can essentially compute forever, affordably.

Frameworks can split work under the hood and express an ergonomic DX to you. So, why split work? You don't want a process to spend 5 hours draining LLM tokens,  then suddenly fail 4 hours and 50 seconds in, and have to star over. Checkpoints are good, actually.

‚è≤Ô∏è We shipped a dearly, dearly requested improvement: longer execution times on @vercel Functions.

(and thanks to Fluid's Active CPU pricing, you don't have to stress over duration or timeouts‚Ä¶ you pay for what you compute. It's good.)

A good reminder for builders is that someone adopting your product happens in two moments. 1Ô∏è‚É£ awareness 2Ô∏è‚É£ low-friction first use. People use products when they *need* them.

As an example, someone pitched me their pre-release ‚Äúai-native photoshop‚Äù the other day. I went to the site and roughly got the idea. It helped that the product itself was the website so I understood the idea faster by messing with it, rather than marketing fluff.

However, just now I actually had a use case. I was astonished by how good this thing is. It worked first try and I‚Äôm now entering the ‚Äúholy shit‚Äù phase. 

The first time I used it was the awareness development moment. If the product builder expected a successful ‚Äúsession‚Äù then, he would have set himself up for disappointment.

The second moment was the crucial one. Users‚Äô attention spans, propensity to go through yet another tool, signup, etc are very low. That second moment needed to be flawless and it was.

Incidentally this is why you need to really pick your battles with product surface and optimize for quality. Had that second moment not been successful, I don‚Äôt know if I would have tried it again for a while. Anecdotally, people seem to do an ‚Äúexponential back off‚Äù with products they‚Äôre disappointed by. They won‚Äôt try you again next week, they‚Äôll try you again in a few months, maybe after another awareness moment in between.

Over the past few months I‚Äôve watched a small, insanely talented team at Vercel live-migrate 100 million functions from a former vendor to Vercel.

Quite a feat of engineering. The scale involved was non-trivial (single-digit % of total vercel functions) but this particular workload ended up being more niche than we anticipated. More on that later.

The more painful lessons are in the runtime engineering aspect. It‚Äôs abundantly clear at this point that nothing can add more tech debt, pain, and degrade the DX more than an exotic runtime with a limited ecosystem. This is why you‚Äôve seen Node.js endure as the standard.

We‚Äôve designed Fluid to be runtime agnostic from the outset. Our functions run stock Node.js & Python, and we‚Äôll make it easy to bring arbitrary ones while retaining the infra benefits like cold start prevention (‚Äúscale to 1‚Äù for prod), multi-region, streaming, etc.

But there‚Äôs an important missing piece. Tune in on June 25: https://t.co/qgIxLgOAFB

Dynamic config change that uncovers a pathologically slow, expensive, or faulty code path is the most common category of global outages. 

Fastly (June 8 2021)¬π
We experienced a global outage due to an undiscovered software bug that surfaced on June 8 when it was triggered by a valid customer configuration change. We detected the disruption within one minute, then identified and isolated the cause, and disabled the configuration

Cloudflare (July 12 2019)¬≤
On July 2, we deployed a new rule in our WAF Managed Rules that caused CPUs to become exhausted on every CPU core that handles HTTP/HTTPS traffic on the Cloudflare network worldwide

Facebook (October 4 2021)¬≥
Our engineering teams have learned that configuration changes on the backbone routers that coordinate network traffic between our data centers caused issues that interrupted this communication.

There‚Äôs several reasons for this:
- Config changes can happen ‚Äúout of band‚Äù, in dynamic runtime systems that are divorced from source control and standard review patterns
- Config changes are sometimes run imperatively by operators. Running scripts, migrations, commands are examples of this
- Even at 100% test code coverage, specific input shapes and sizes can bite you and slip by 
- Config changes can uncover latent software bugs. Like a pathogen that‚Äôs been dormant and gets activated later. It can be very difficult to forensically map the config change to code that might have been introduced weeks, months, years ago. The typical incident response is to look at *recent* code changes 
- The worst kind, as in the Fastly case: multi-tenant systems accept dynamic user configuration changes. In the case of Vercel, we let our millions of users dynamically change any aspect of our CDN: routes, settings, headers, middleware code.

What do we do to prevent this? 

First, know that this is very hard work. Infrastructure work requires extreme attention and paranoia. I sympathize with these teams.

1Ô∏è‚É£The first is to treat every change as code. I‚Äôve shared this banger by @hugelgupf before:

> Configurations, rules, policies, whatever you call them -- they're all code. Roll em out like code.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Have operational limits on everything. ‚ÄúUnlimited‚Äù is the worst kind of engineering marketing, avoid it like the plague. A system without limits is a system that will eventually go down or not scale properly.

For instance, Vercel applies strict limits to the configuration options we give customers, and we even set upper bounds on the max number of cpu cycles regular expressions can incur in.

Recursion is your enemy. Regular expressions can be exploited via backtracking. Redirects can be exploited by redirecting the host to itself. Etc

3Ô∏è‚É£ Broad system changes require careful follow-on monitoring

The worst character trait for an engineering operating at scale is over-confidence. It‚Äôs imperative to monitor the effects of the change. It doesn‚Äôt matter what programming language, type checker, effect system you‚Äôre using.

What the Reddit post says is consistent with every Cloudflare contract we've seen.

First, very importantly, you charge for bandwidth. Second, you have 'max allocations' on a per item basis. Third, you have a clause in the contract that says that the prices listed do not apply to overages. The enterprise rep can re-negotiate them arbitrarily at will.

Increasing convinced observability and monitoring as it exists today will soon cease to exist. Two counter trends: autonomous infrastructure & AI.

Humans staring at plots and charts to derive very obvious patterns like why your API is 500ing is NGMI.

On one hand we have infra that scales automatically and self-heals. A lot of our customers simply don‚Äôt set up expensive o11y appliances. Prices will go down to approach the cost of data storage. On the other hand, we have the fact that people don‚Äôt want o11y, they want solutions.

They want pull requests with fixes, they want automatic rollbacks, they want automatic fail over of vendors (see: AI Gateway).

Because Fluid is adjusting at the time of integration and tuned for each runtime, it‚Äôs more efficient, faster and automatic.

Autoscaling requires a lot of manual tuning, CPU thresholds, and can react too slowly. We all hate cold starts, but a request queued behind an unresponsive & overloaded server / VPS is effectively a cold start or worse.
@haltakov Will check with the team. Our default stance is to benchmark against our past selves and recommend customers do their own. Benchmark marketing can quickly end up contrived.

Another example of how AI disrupts everything, from UIs to infrastructure: serverless. You can‚Äôt take tomorrow for granted‚Ä¶

The model that Lambda pioneered was 1 invocation 1 function instance. This works wonderfully if your databases and caches respond instantly, as they should! This was the norm for SaaS and e-commerce.

When GPT APIs came out and developers saw the opportunity to create AI products, two new profiles emerged:

‚ñ™Ô∏è Streaming responses
‚ñ™Ô∏è Lots of idle time & long responses

Luckily for us, we had been working hard on streaming in preparation for React Server Components. We knew that for complex frontends with lots of data and components, the best model was to render and return as soon as possible. That investment in streaming paid off.

Idle time posed a significant challenge. A system optimized for fast computation suddenly had workloads that were taking 30s to respond. And then reasoning models come out, and we‚Äôre now talking minutes. And then agents come out, and we‚Äôre talking hours? Days!?

Our team moved extraordinarily quickly while operating at very large scale. We created üåä Fluid which solves the idle time problem by sending more requests to existing function instances. 

Like a VPS would. But unlike a VPS, if the instance is overloaded and blocked by compute, it intelligently launches a new instance in parallel to accommodate. Think of this as just-in-time, invocation-driven, dynamic load balancing.

The customer win concretely is that we‚Äôve saved people a lot of money. Up to 90% cost reductions for some workloads by just turning Fluid on, which, unlike other solutions, requires no code changes and runs full, off-the-shelf, versioned Node.js and Python.

We‚Äôre very privileged to host many of the most popular AI apps in the world. With one of them we got to see Jevons Paradox up close while in beta. We saved them a lot of money, we scaled with them as the service took off, they continued to innovate and launch new things on Vercel. The savings over time just translated into more service demand, because we helped them win.

We‚Äôve got a few more things coming to Fluid that I think you‚Äôll love, especially for building these kinds of AI apps. You can read more about this topic here: 

https://t.co/wzzQfSwaBY

Amazon famously popularized the finding that for each 100ms of slowdown in their storefront, they‚Äôd see a 1% drop in conversion.

We‚Äôve found this effect to be far more pronounced with @v0. Speed and reliability have an outsized effect on engagement and conversion.

There‚Äôre a couple reasons for this. On a high level, AIs are evolving to be our virtual coworkers. Intuitively, we‚Äôd all much rather work with coworkers that respond to our @ pings and emails instantly. Coworkers that get back to us reliably and don‚Äôt drop the ball.

These problems are very real in AI today, which is why I‚Äôm so excited about our AI Gateway[1] and investments into reliable streaming[2].

AI can be, conservatively, 10x faster and more reliable than it is today, and this will be a vital part of the race for consumers building the muscle memory in favor of a certain agent, much like it played out for so many of us defaulting to typing amazon dot com.

[2] https://t.co/jdFS697uYu

When I started Vercel my singular obsession was ‚Äútime to deploy URL‚Äù, in the fewest number of commands and config (`now`).

Our next frontier: time to intelligence. By building on the @aisdk, all you have to do is install the dep:

‚ñ≤ ~ / npm i ai@alpha @vercel/ai-sdk-gateway

Then run `vc pull` for local development support. That‚Äôs it.

To try or switch models just swap a string, like ‚Äúùöçùöéùöéùöôùöúùöéùöéùöî/ùöçùöéùöéùöôùöúùöéùöéùöî-ùöõùü∑‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúùö°ùöäùöí/ùöêùöõùöòùöî-ùüπ-ùöãùöéùöùùöä‚Äù. No API tokens. No new accounts. Unified usage billing with observability.

Our AI gateway comes from the lessons of building @v0 and powering many of the largest AI apps today on Vercel‚Äôs infra.

The realities today:

‚ñ´AI labs move at breakneck speed. Your best play is to minimize switching costs and preserve option value without lock-in.
‚ñ´The demand for AI is so extreme that even the largest clouds struggle with capacity issues that result in frequent rate-limiting errors.
‚ñ´The infrastructure is not as mature, stable, and predictable as the ‚Äúsoftware 1.0‚Äù cloud services yet. Backups and failovers are even more essential.
‚ñ´As open models progress, the competition for best price/performance intensifies, because many vendors can serve the weights. You will be able to name the open model ID and delegate the optimal vendor choice to the gateway.

We‚Äôre super excited about the AI Gateway solving these challenges and many more as it evolves. Please try it out and share your feedback!

@a_i_m_rue Active area of research for us, we have a few good hypotheses

The rise and fall (and rise) of the CDN.

App developers and vibe coders will never have to think about CDN and WAF as distinct appliances to purchase and configure. The CDN has been turned inside out: its configuration and caching are outputs of the deployment process and Git-driven. This is a major disruption.

Enterprises are arriving to the same conclusion. As they modernize their apps, rewrite them in modern frameworks, and deploy to the cloud, they‚Äôll realize their multi-year CDN contracts are technically redundant and predatory from a cost perspective, with non-transparent pricing and outdated configuration management (usually ClickOps, developer-hostile and professional services heavy).

But how do we get to the promised land of full automation with optimal global distribution and efficiency? For Vercel this means to continue to invest in framework-defined infrastructure for net-new apps, but also smoothing the road to use Vercel as a pure CDN/WAF to facilitate incremental migrations. Their journey to a high performance, AI-native app will start one microfrontend at a time, with the rest of traffic proxied to the existing workloads.

Over the past few weeks we‚Äôve shipped very exciting CDN and security features:

‚ñ™Vary HTTP header support
‚ñ™1-click AI crawlers blocking 
‚ñ™CDN-Cache-Control proxy support
‚ñ™Increased origin timeout to 120s
‚ñ™Better bot observability 
‚ñ™Easier custom WAF rule creation 
‚ñ™1-click Bot filter / challenging 

With lots more to come. Excited to be making all new apps fast and secure, while giving a clear path forward to the large and complex websites and apps we depend on every day.

Congrats to the @neondatabase team on their acquisition by @databricks. It‚Äôs clear that serverless and open source data was not just what developers wanted, but also the ideal foundation for coding agents to build on.

Agents like @v0 favor infrastructure that‚Äôs well represented in the training (Postgres: check). Not re-inventing the wheel and bringing new query languages to market was rewarded.

On the other hand, agents and modern dev platforms like @vercel need agility. Databases need to be created instantly when you prompt or create from a template. During the vibe coding or preview process, the database is needed, but then not accessed for a while.

At rest, a Neon database is inexpensive S3 objects. Modernizing the storage layer, while retaining the ‚Äúfrontend‚Äù APIs that agents and devs are familiar with is a winning combination. 

It‚Äôs great to see new players in the Postgres space like https://t.co/QR9Mw4BKzv, https://t.co/BDjniVkUQH, https://t.co/zjjtxnz4aU innovating in the storage infrastructure as well. @Supabase recently announced the acquisition of https://t.co/xNJospTeCl to pursue decoupled storage and compute, while @Prisma is bringing a Unikernel-based approach for instant db boots with https://t.co/6KPUinWmtQ.

It‚Äôs clear now that Postgres has become the Linux of the database world, and the de-facto choice of developers, enterprises, and importantly, agents.

There‚Äôs more we‚Äôre building on top of this you can look forward to. For instance, being able to diff the generated infrastructure across environments. Helps you understand what the impact will be as you go from preview to production.

üá™üá∏üö´ Update on LaLiga's blocks. We've been working with their team to ensure uninterrupted access in Spain to the @vercel global CDN.

Vercel has set up a dedicated inbox for LaLiga to file reports. Sadly, they just blocked another Vercel CDN IP without using this mechanism.

To summarize the situation so far:
‚óÜ A soccer organization should *not* have the ability to broadly block internet infrastructure access to millions of Spanish customers across major internet service providers.
‚óÜ CDN providers like Vercel front millions of mission-critical websites and applications behind the IPs being blocked. Even in the situation a block is required, it can be done on a hostname basis via TLS SNI, rather than IP.
‚óÜ We set up an inbox that's tied into our Site Reliability Engineering's incident management system to process high priority requests. It has so far been unused.

We're closely monitoring the situation and continue to offer our assistance to LaLiga to minimize the blast radius of these blocks and help preserve free access to the internet in Spain.

I love this model and it‚Äôs what we built with Fluid. 

First, on the shoulders of Lambda, we shipped the 1:1 process-to-request model. The DX was sublime but if you‚Äôre waiting on I/O for long it can become inefficient, especially with LLM streaming which can take a while.

Then, since developers were still writing async/await code rather than blocking the main thread and there‚Äôs an ecosystem around it, it was a no-brainer to ‚Äúpack‚Äù the already-running functions more densely. There‚Äôs a lot of intelligence in the system though.

If your function is waiting on a backend, then we can send more requests to an instance. But if your function is doing number-crunching, image transformation, you-name-it CPU-blocking operations, we spin up more. This solves a very tricky, usually-manual and error-prone, load balancing problem.

We‚Äôll be sharing more technical notes on how the dynamic load balancing logic works, but in the mean time, here‚Äôs a write up. Excited for others to explore this space.

Will we hire engineers in the future?

Prompting is thinking. The sharper your thoughts, the better the prompts, the better the outputs. Engineering and design are headed into a world where most of the output is produced by prompting, if not all.

The way we interview engineers has already been trending in this direction. At Vercel, we don‚Äôt care if you memorized every API and module. When we look at your coding, we assess the quality of your thinking and collaboration. It‚Äôs more so an evaluation of your ‚Äúthinking tokens‚Äù or reasoning trace. In fact, the more you expose it, walking through how you backtrack, pivot, adjust, consult, the better signal we get.

My prediction is that the demand for great thinkers will remain unabated. It‚Äôs unclear if we‚Äôll call them engineers or if it‚Äôll matter, because these people will have a lot of full stack impact on the whole business, as they‚Äôll have access to prompt their way to any successful outcome.

Google Chrome ending up in the wrong hands due to DOJ intervention could be catastrophic for the open web and backfire entirely. 

Few organizations in the world meet the bar of having 1Ô∏è‚É£ the web‚Äôs best interests in mind, 2Ô∏è‚É£ the technical infrastructure and know-how, and 3Ô∏è‚É£ the immense required funding.

Working on a browser involves two main areas: the engine and its frontend, like a car‚Äôs engine and its chassis & dashboard. Google has done a *phenomenal* job on the engine, which is one of the absolute hardest technical undertakings in the world, and curiously enough is actually fully open source.

Blink, Chrome‚Äôs engine, is BSD and LGPL licensed, developed in the open, and powers so many of Google‚Äôs competitors, including Microsoft Edge, Brave, Opera, Vivaldi, Browser Company‚Äôs Arc/Dia, and dozens of others at no cost. It‚Äôs absolutely essential that this work stays uninterrupted, while we continue to invest as a community in engine diversity, including projects like @ladybirdbrowser of which I‚Äôm a proud backer.

And Blink is just one piece, in charge of rendering. Google has built and open sourced many other crucial engine components like the V8 JavaScript engine, Skia, PDFium, Cronet, and many others, bundled as part of the open Chromium distribution. The complexity of what makes a modern browser work is truly staggering. Thank you Google.

The DOJ is taking particular issue with the engine‚Äôs frontend, the actual thing consumers download and interact with. This is where Google has the unique privilege to package and distribute the open source engine components, and impose arbitrary rules and configurations on top, like search engine defaults, AI assistance models, telemetry capture, login / accounts integration, settings and history sync, Web Store rules (like which ad blockers can be distributed), etc. At the scale Google is operating and the power it confers, scrutiny and caution here is warranted.

I believe, however, that the best path forward will be an incremental one, maintaining the careful balance of a browser frontend that has the everyday internet citizen‚Äôs best interests in mind, while not disrupting the investment and support of such crucial open internet infrastructure that benefits us all.

Because we build @v0 full stack on Vercel, we've been able to experience what a successful startup born on our platform would live through, as fate would have it, on an expedited timeline. It's been validating.

Takeaways. The most important thing to optimize for is iteration velocity. We noticed that LLMs were not just good at writing haikus and homework, but also writing React and Tailwind. @jaredpalmer came up with the 'text to React component' interface and launched it extremely quickly.

Since then, *major* advancements have happened in the ecosystem. Model innovations. Better cognitive architectures. Prompting techniques. Retrieval solutions. Tool calls. Integrations. We co-evolved the @aisdk as a universal interface to AI models because we realized the future of intelligence would not belong to one specific vendor.

Today, that single Postgres instance we started with has its days numbered. We'll have to shard and replicate to keep up with demand. But looking back, I wouldn't change a thing. The success of a product is rooted in how fast it evolves. We made the right bets to be able to iterate on the customer experience, while replacing some of the backend components as we went along.

That was the premise with which we started @nextjs and @vercel, as well as open sourcing the tools and best practices of what we learn as a team‚Ä¶ so, stay tuned for more of the behind the scenes of our evolving database architecture üôÇ

When FoundationDB was introduced to the world, its cofounders would do live demonstrations of its fault tolerance properties by physically unplugging servers and simulating power failures in one or more machines.

The entire system was first conceived and developed in a fully simulated environment. Actual storage, clocks, and network code came later, once the baseline of confidence was established. Because hardware and cloud engineering has gotten so good, running into these failures is rare, which can lead to sloppy engineering.

This is the ideal acid test that we must run software through. We must first develop in environments in which the proverbial "tripping over the cables" is handled by design. When we ship, we must do so with the confidence that the corner cases are handled.

The corollary is that when you QA your software, you must be ready to unplug the server and see how it responds. Too often I see product people treat their creations like a delicate flower, ignore flakes, blame 'the internet', press the refresh button‚Ä¶ living in blissful ignorance of the pain users will face in the real world.

We're cooking up a mechanism to seamlessly resume streams and share state across Fluid functions.

AI apps pose an interesting challenge to developers: they need to stream feedback in realtime, they have multiple agents behind the scenes, the conversation needs to be shareable, resumable, survive network disconnections.

Even with https://t.co/v6M4VQNaw0, this kind of stuff was non-trivial. You always need a durability source (in this demo below, you can see the 'stream id' in the URL), so a stateful bidirectional transport like WebSocket is *not enough*. Not only is it not enough, it's also not necessary (the demo below uses good ol' HTTP streaming).

Also: what happens if the stateful Node WebSocket server was re-deployed mid-stream? or if it crashed? how do the streams recover?

I'm excited for @vercel to give you all the primitives to execute on applications that raise the bar on not just performance, but also on fault tolerance. h/t @cramforce for sweating the details here.

The cool tech thing here: if you go to `/state-of-ai` right now, you get an instant CDN load of the 404 page. When it ships, you'll get an instant CDN load of the (PPR) survey page.

What makes this a particularly neat feat is that the flag evaluation is instant and globally distributed. In principle, this flag thing would "just" be an extra line in your page render function:

  ùöíùöè (ùöèùöïùöäùöêùô¥ùöóùöäùöãùöïùöéùöç) {

‚Ä¶ but that would force everything into a regional server-render. It'd make everything slower and more expensive. If you're not extremely careful, when you get a spike of traffic it would then denial-of-service your CMS and databases. And this was "just" a landing page!

Vercel solves this with global middleware and first-class support for flags (https://t.co/c8eX4NLbUh) that is easy to integrate on top of your pages, which get statically optimized as necessary (e.g.: with @nextjs). The Toolbar then allows your team to override and simulate the values of these flags.

This is an example of something that has been historically quite hard to do on the web, even though it 'looks' so simple on the surface. You can make it globally fast, reliable, cost-efficient, *and* roll it out in a collaborative way with your team that minimizes risk.

Helping a customer migrate from an existing CDN to Vercel. This service advertises itself as not charging for bandwidth. 

Extensive marketing plastered all over social media. Imagine my surprise when I look at their renewal order form‚Ä¶ first 2 items? Bandwidth and Requests.

The reality: the service is "free an unlimited" until their Enterprise sales team gets their hands on you. And they will. They're hoping that you're in too deep at that point. They're hoping that they can crowd social media with enough loud voices about how awesome the "free" service is.

Leaving the business model aside, is this how you want to live? The fundamental feedback loop of engineering is one in which you understand your costs, transparently, and how they scale. You make engineering choices, down to the code you write, based on that feedback loop.

What's astonishing about this order form is just how similar the pricing is to a hyperscaler cloud. Except every real cloud provider operating at scale can't afford to deceive the world, and then play a game of chicken with ToS threats and sales teams. Which is why my prediction is that the music will be stopping soon.

Lots to love about this release.

1Ô∏è‚É£ The beginning of arguably the most exciting journey in @nextjs history: Turbopack production builds.

Like with our `next dev` efforts, focusing on the cold case first, we've been able to bring down one of the world's largest Next.js codebases, Vercel, from 7m 25s to 1m 6s, by using our new Rust-powered compiler which scales beautifully with the number of CPU cores in build machines. Things will get even wilder once incremental caching is enabled.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Partnering with the ecosystem (@rspack_dev) to make sure we speed up *everyone*, including complex webpack-centric setups & mature codebases.

Turbopack is extremely exciting, but since we started this project, we've been committed to backwards compatibility. For example, you can use 15.3 with Pages Router and styled-jsx if you'd like. In line with this commitment, we believe Rspack can help tremendously with codebases that have lots of webpack extensions that Turbopack doesn't support.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Better client routing support

We've heard a lot of feedback that you want more routing flexibility client-side. Excited to give you fine-grained control for navigations. Finally an elegant way to do transition animations ü´°

At ~7,000 RPS, deploying several times per hour, whether you‚Äôre an intern or senior member of the technical staff. 

Truly zero downtime deployments & rollbacks that propagate instantly worldwide. 

The globally atomic, skew-free nature of the system is what gives us confidence. Consider this: as a simplification, Vercel‚Äôs frontend is 3 bundles: a CDN middleware function, a server rendering function, and a client side bundle. For the app to successfully load, all three not only have to be available and 200, but the versions need to be synchronized. 

It‚Äôs ‚Äúno bueno‚Äù to run middleware that‚Äôs propagating through space and time for version N of the app, then serve static assets from another version, that then invoke a route handler of another version‚Ä¶ in fact, it‚Äôd be catastrophic. This is what causes companies to deploy once a quarter, at midnight, or whenever their order or transaction volume is low.

I‚Äôm convinced the gap in experience between a native mobile app and a mobile web app boils down primarily to user input at this point. 

The performance gap is illusory for most use-cases & devices. Safari iOS handling of how a keyboard displays, the havoc it wreaks on the page, and limited APIs to control it are a fundamental issue.

Once 120fps animations are enabled by default that‚Äôll be the icing on the cake. But any diminishment in the ability for a human to reliably enter information into the page is a deal breaker.

Secure vibe coding

@v0 has now prevented LLMs from writing vulnerable code in 16,200+ generated applications. Concretely, it's prevented *sixteen thousand* token leaks, from AI api keys to database compromises.

How does this work?
‚Ä¢ From a threat model perspective, v0 doesn't take LLM code for granted. We consider all code potentially incorrect or adversarial.
‚Ä¢ Next.js makes a strong distinction between server-side tokens and client-side tokens, which are `NEXT_PUBLIC_` prefixed.
‚Ä¢ v0 analyzes `NEXT_PUBLIC_` usage and warns the user. Because we have support for server-side code execution, the code can then be easily moved to Route Handlers / Server Actions / etc by the AI.

Further, when v0 deploys to @vercel, server-side code becomes secure Functions that run in isolated sandboxes and read encrypted environment from our built-in secure vault.

We're continuing our research and investment into guardrails so that v0 users can ship with confidence. Our goal is to make v0 generated applications more secure than human-written ones. Shoutout to @ido_pesok for laying the groundwork in this area.
v0 is soon becoming even faster! Our goal is to be the fastest and easiest AI development platform in the world

The reason there‚Äôs no universe is that you‚Äôre downloading a large response body, vs a Location header. Your own screenshot shows this in the ‚Äúcontent transfer‚Äù part.

Btw, the vercel homepage is dynamically computed (edge middleware determines flags / experiments among other things) prior to hitting the static cache. 

The link redirect is the same for every user. You‚Äôre imagining computation that‚Äôs not there. If the domain is flagged, it‚Äôs flagged for every link click, globally. That can be checked in single digit ms with active replication ahead of time.
@nicoritschel Good call
@jessethanley @jetpackjoe_ Look at the server processing step! The vercel response is dominated by compute and large content transfer of a very large response, not a header.

I‚Äôll give you an additional mental model for you to chew on: pull vs push. 

If a domain gets reported, you should not wait until a link gets clicked. In fact, given the risk that someone might list copy and paste the URL, you should propagate that information ahead of time.

This should work very much like suspended accounts. Every tweet and reference gets disabled recursively.

This would allow X to do whatever enforcement without nasty short urls, and it‚Äôd be a more comprehensive protection for users.

Now let‚Äôs assume they can‚Äôt do that. The second best thing to do is to make t co fast. You can do this by making the spam and metadata database globally replicate. The time to do a check if the link is active or flagged as phishing should be less than 1ms. The round trip time from network edge to one of the 8 regions I outlined will likely be in the order of <20ms.

There‚Äôs no universe in which my website with all its HTML and edge middleware should return 2x faster than an empty response with a Location header, from San Francisco, and it gets much worse in other parts of the world.

Hope this helps!
