Some that come to mind:

- Infrastructure is an output, not an input. The input is developer / vibecoder intent
- Framework is the right abstraction point to capture intent & provide guardrails / defaults for optimization
- Static and dynamic are not ‚Äúmodes‚Äù of deployment. Static is best thought of as an ahead-of-time memoization / cache. It‚Äôs a ‚Äúknown subset‚Äù of dynamic, and they can coexist in one response (PPR)
- Function is the right abstraction for interactive compute. The incoming HTTP request triggering the function invocation add vital knowledge to the scheduling / placement / load balancing systems.
- LLMs benefit greatly from well-defined abstraction boundaries that are composable and can be reasoned about locally. This is why @v0 is so good at Tailwind and React

The DOM properties `className` and `htmlFor` were named as such to prevent conflicts with the reserved language keywords.

React decided to align itself with the DOM APIs. It could have called them `class` and safely map them to the DOM properties under the hood, especially given JSX would not have been served directly to old JS engines where the keyword could be a conflict (like IE8).

Now the shipped has sailed. Even if supported was added for `class`, the entire ecosystem has been built on top of the assumption of `className`

@0xblacklight @bunjavascript Turbopack is written in native code so the JS runtime should not matter. It should work just fine with any Node-compatible runtime. I think they‚Äôre improving their Node compat right now which should bear fruit

HMR & AI

Over the past decade, web frameworks and bundlers have been optimizing for HMR (hot module replacement) and Fast Refresh for React. 

The main idea of HMR is that as a human developer makes changes to the source code, we want changes reflect to instantly in the web browser.

This technology is highly prolific among web developers, but less common in other ecosystems. In fact, one of my motivations for starting @nextjs as a zero-config framework was that I was absolutely over-the-moon with this capability, and while Webpack was pioneering its support, it was too tedious to configure. I wanted it batteries-included.

Over the past few years, as dependency trees have grown, icon libraries, barrel files, and npm packages proliferated, the sheer amount of frontend source code increased dramatically. So began the journey of Turbopack, which consisted in a new architecture and design, as well as rewriting the compiler to Rust, away from JavaScript-based Webpack. 

Modern compilers like Turbopack are insanely fast at HMR, and only getting faster. With its incremental design and down-to-the-metal optimization, we‚Äôre giving feedback to the user in what might just be the absolute theoretical minimum of what computers are capable of. It‚Äôs not infrequent to see ‚Äúcode to visible change‚Äù in single digit milliseconds.

While we originally conceived Turbopack for humans, I believe it‚Äôs going to play a key role in the feedback loop with AI coding agents. LLMs are not full-proof at writing code. They make mistakes and need feedback, and we want to spend as little time as possible in that compiler-agent loop. They will cook, see the output or read the error, cook again‚Ä¶

I think more broadly this speaks to the advantage the web has in this new chapter of software development. The web is more fluid, the feedback loop faster, the deployment model ideal. AI will massively increase the number of applications written and shipped, and I believe most of them will be web based.

@royalicing Yes, which is why I made the point that your backend needs to be fast too. Notice there‚Äôs no ‚ÄúSPA‚Äù experience for them. It‚Äôs the ‚Äútime to content‚Äù that‚Äôs fast.

But as a *user* I absolutely need to know if the write has been confirmed or not, which is why I like the current experience.

@iangrayhazzard @zero__ms I‚Äôm very open minded about it provided it delivers on the axioms I outlined: fast loads, fast navigations, no excessive initial blocking downloads.

I know that Next, RSC and e.g.: Postgres can give you this with an excellent DX (simple data queries from ‚Äútemplates‚Äù ala LAMP)

Some people pointed out that https://t.co/Zggoe9nRo1 is very aggressive with prefetching. This is because I set it to prefetch={true} which prefetches data. Postgres is eating that up for breakfast with zero issues, but it‚Äôs still opt-in. With this example I wanted to demonstrate what the ideal experience we should strive for should be.

You have another two options:
- Prefetch the loading state. This is the SPA feel. But let‚Äôs not kid ourselves. People want fast content, not just fast spinners
- Not prefetch anything! This is how https://t.co/marktAlOMG works. Just block until the content is fetched on-demand.

I personally think it‚Äôs awesome that developers have this kind of flexibility. I also think @nextjs could potentially do batch prefetching (I have to concede I haven‚Äôt thought about this too deeply yet, no pun intended) and massively reduce the number of requests.

I believe we should as a community and industry push for the absolute fastest and most delightful experiences, not decelerate the web.

One of the coolest properties of the web, that I believe we must preserve at all costs, is that each hyperlink within a system can be a portal into arbitrary amounts of complexity, *without paying that cost up front*.

If we forego this, we‚Äôll end up with Facebook‚Äôs 490MB iOS[1] download, random spinners on Home Screen while apps download, and a really hard time onboarding new users.

There‚Äôs lots of discussion on SPA vs RSC, so it‚Äôs worth clarifying our vision with @nextjs.

First, instant load times are non-negotiable. Starting with when you first get linked into an app or website. Notice I don‚Äôt make a distinction here: app or website. I think the web has given rise to amazing things like being linked to a GitHub PR or Vercel deploy, and getting the content you want ASAP instead of downloading a 500mb app.

But it‚Äôs also absolutely paramount that *subsequent clicks or taps* are also instantaneous, which is where traditional websites fall short. Next.js accomplishes this via prefetching, otherwise we fall back into the trap of *downloading the entire codebase* for any of the possible futures the user might take.

Next.js with RSC and partial pre-rendering is the perfect platform to yield this best of both worlds situation. I think most apps will want to pre-fetch the *next screen minus the data*, and what‚Äôs cool about this is that we do it based on the viewport, and we prefetch exactly what that user will need. Including flags and experiments that the given user is enrolled in. This is, incidentally, why something like Facebook ends up getting so big. As projects grow, engineers get ambitious about experiments, features, regional capabilities, seasonal promotions, and so on. With RSC, we solve the problem that both code and data can be highly dynamic.

In short, combining really fast load times with instant page navigations, not at the expense of downloading a gigantic monolithic app ahead of time with a spinner, is how the web wins. This is why we created Next.js in the first place[2]

[2] https://t.co/KAkwL3xOZz

You‚Äôre seeing this dialog because you have the option to stay on the older image optimization pricing model while you tune things.

Vercel has a new, transparent pricing image optimization pricing model that charges for the compute incurred in optimizing images as needed. Before it was per ‚Äúsource image‚Äù, now it‚Äôs per transformation and cache usage. Optimizing images incurs in non-trivial amounts of computation, so it has a cost, and this better models it.

The reason we recommend optimization by default is to ensure optimal performance for users and CWV (Core Web Vitals) for your business and your SEO. As a matter of fact, this change in Next.js came from our partnership with Google Chrome‚Äôs Aurora team, who noticed the vast majority of sites on the internet are shipping large images which specially hurt mobile users.

The üîë piece: there are plenty of options available to you, from disabling optimization, to doing it at build time, to changing the optimization provider. Sometimes it‚Äôs a simple as improving the caching lifetime on the images. We wrote docs on how to manage this:

https://t.co/NlxiGg1u7X

Our goal is to always lead with transparency and options for you, and we try our best to make the web as fast a possible, by default.

You already don't need Cloudflare, which is what's probably triggering @eastdakota's anxiety and having him resort to childlike tactics and memes:

‚óæÔ∏é Built-in DDoS mitigation. As I mentioned above, we actually mitigate attacks Cloudflare doesn't. We know this because some customers layer them in front of us, and we have to block Cloudflare passing on the attack.
‚óæÔ∏é Firewall / WAF. You can apply custom rules based on headers, IPs. We support rate limiting and persistent actions. We have support for JA3 and JA4 TLS fingerprints, which is a mechanism to more precisely identifying potential bad actors. You can outright block, or challenge traffic to ascertain the client is a human.
‚óæÔ∏é Programmable security. You can control our Firewall programmatically via REST APIs or Terraform. We also have Firewall templates for easily creating rules, like blocking AI crawlers.
‚óæÔ∏é World-class, realtime observability. You can dry-run Firewall changes in log-only mode to carefully roll out changes. You can make queries over billions of datapoints in milliseconds.
‚óæÔ∏é Attack Challenge Mode. If you want to have a 'break glass' "I'm under attack" measure you can click one toggle and immediately challenge traffic. 
‚óæÔ∏é Secure Compute for Functions. You can run compute that's securely bound to e.g.: your AWS VPC environments. This is infinitely safer than Cloudflare's Workers approach, which has customers usually exposing their databases to the internet.

+ a long laundry list of capabilities like OIDC, RBAC, Audit Logs, ‚Ä¶

Single-threaded personal AI. Chatbots today assume that you‚Äôll have multiple ‚Äúconversations‚Äù and they‚Äôll try to collect memories about you. In practice this is quite clunky. There might be an opportunity to break the mold, and maybe for a narrow usecase (like a truly personal assistant / confidant, rather than a general purpose search engine), have an app where it‚Äôs truly just one long chat. It‚Äôs all memories and context, that gets compressed in layers of memories over time to fit into the context (much like S3 storage tiers and CPU caches)

More granular @v0‚Äãs. Like v0 for CAD (https://t.co/Z7VIrH3VVq), Postgres (https://t.co/05Ibcz9BMY), Email templates (https://t.co/Ajl3l3JKg3), consider ideas like an SVG and vector AI builder, an AI email composer (no reads, just writes), game asset builder, mock data generator‚Ä¶ endless possibilities. Explore common file types and work backwards to an AI-native production UX. Check out our template https://t.co/yGi4vzJ6tZ for the chat + artifacts/canvas UI already implanted in @nextjs (OSS).

Absurdly smart autocomplete. Throughout your day, as you switch between apps, you‚Äôre carrying information from context to context. You might read something on X and then discuss it with someone on Slack. This context today is lost. Spell checkers and autocompleters don‚Äôt understand nor know the very thing you just wrote about, let alone memes, codenames, brand names, etc. This can be a significant leap forward in cognitive power. It‚Äôs stateful and context-rich autocomplete that always learns.

AI-native Google Forms that is purely conversational. You set up the form or survey by just writing down a bunch of prompts. It gives you a link you can share for people to ‚Äúfill out the form‚Äù. But it‚Äôs just a chat UI. Who wants to press ‚Äúother‚Äù and fill in a little textbox when you could just answer? Just like Typeform innovated in the UI of answering, AI provides an opportunity to improve both the creation and submission experience.

AI Camera. Point your camera to something, and just like Instagram offered ‚Äúfilters‚Äù to solve your photography skill issue, this offers a strip of little permutations of the photo. The classic example is: take bad photo of the full moon, or 4th of July fireworks from your backyard, or that overexposed Eiffel Tower shot at night‚Ä¶ this will make it actually good. Make it extremely trivial to prompt for changes, including with a brush on the photo.

When people or AIs write code for an app, it needs to be built. Building optimizes the code and makes it a working app. The result gets deployed to a URL people can access.

Because that code can be dangerous, we need to make sure it can‚Äôt hack other people‚Äôs code and data. We achieve this by isolating it in virtual computers that need to be ‚Äúexorcised‚Äù after. They‚Äôre untrusted.

We now create and destroy one million of these computers a day.

Because AI is making it easier to create applications, including non-developers, we suspect this infrastructure will grow exponentially in coming years. The faster you make this build process (which Vercel is investing heavily into), the faster AI agents (which are not infallible) can learn and correct errors.

The other stuff is a bunch of technical terms of how we make these virtual machines very reliable and work as expected.

Vercel is now consistently handling over 1M builds a day every day.

That‚Äôs 1M microVMs (virtual mini cloud computers) instantly booting, running user code in a secure sandbox, and being destroyed every day.

There‚Äôs an enormous amount of complexity being handled behind the scenes by the mighty @vercel infra team so that when you click on ‚ÄúDeploy‚Äù in @v0, import a repo, clone a template, or run `vc` in the CLI, your application code is quickly and securely built, optimized, and deployed globally.

To meet our scale and flexibility needs, we had to build our own custom compute platform powered by Firecracker called Hive[1]. 

We orchestrate Hive clusters in multiple regions worldwide, we handle automatic failover, QoS policies across customer and plan tiers, multiple classes of hardware, pre-warming and snapshotting of containers, custom networking overlays, security patching, Dependabot thundering herds‚Ä¶ We even carefully synchronize OS and Node runtime flavors with your Functions to prevent unsavory production surprises. 

I expect the vast majority of this class of compute to be orchestrated by AIs in the future. Today, when a build @v0 creates ends with a failure (like type checking errors), v0 consumes the logs output and fixes errors automatically.

The speed at which this ‚Äúagentic loop‚Äù happens is a new and very exciting optimization target for us. Stay tuned for announcements in this space.

[1] https://t.co/nptrqIHFN1

This is a very concerning privacy gap in Ô£ø iOS devices. 

The Firewall team @vercel was debugging curious bot-like behavior emerging from an end-user IP (i.e.: a human).

The `User-Agent` header being sent by the device was very strange looking‚Ä¶ Pretending to be Facebook and Twitter at once ü§®.

Turns out that whenever you use the iOS share dialog, a request will be made *from your IP* using this User-Agent. This is quite unexpected, especially if the user is on an app designed for private communication or watching corn.

The fact that the mere act of a sharing intent has this side-effect is concerning in its own right, but it's doubly concerning that the end-user IP is leaked in the process. (If it was an absolute must to fetch metadata about the URL, a privacy-preserving proxy could be used.)

To summarize, this results in:
‚óæÔ∏é A bypass of anonymization / proxying techniques that the app you're using might be implementing. It's generally "good practice" to defer to the OS sharing dialog rather than re-implementing it in every app, but the OS is throwing you under the bus.
‚óæÔ∏é A mechanism for a third party / bad actor to know that a given user is making a decision to share something.
‚óæÔ∏é All the consequences that come from having an end-user IP, including de-anonymization and physical location leak risks.

Next is a platform. Our goal is to have the DX of the ‚Äúmajestic monolith‚Äù, but without any volatile opinions.

@ja3nyc @v0 We‚Äôre strongly steering v0 towards using server components and route handlers for those scenarios. We also pair with our secure @vercel vault for secret storage to prevent leaking via .env files and other common errors.

I strongly believe AIs will create *more* secure, more correct, and more performant software than humans. 

The ‚Äúvibe‚Äù in vibe coding should speak to the creative direction style, rather than the quality of the output. This is certainly our goal with @v0, prevent slop at all costs. 

Agents don‚Äôt get tired, so they‚Äôll make fewer mistakes. It‚Äôs too easy for a human today to forget to auth an endpoint. To not apply operational limits and quotas. To forget to escape and validate untrusted input. 

Interestingly enough, our CTO @cramforce recently discovered a serious vulnerability in an open source project. It involved a lack of sanitization of potentially malicious payloads in a quite subtle, unsuspecting line of code. After our responsible disclosure to their team, I found the PR that introduced their bug and ran it through a few models. Almost all frontier coding models correctly identified the high risk involved in the inlining technique used to pass data to the browser.

It‚Äôs extremely common for human programmers and human reviewers to let these issues slide. That PR was written and reviewed by experts. The same applies to every other important area of software quality. We humans might lapse, rush or simply not know enough and not ship enough tests, accessibility, caching & other performance optimizations‚Ä¶ Agents won‚Äôt forget or be lazy to ship enough instrumentation and alerting so that they themselves can get paged when the site is down.

It won‚Äôt happen overnight and this future will require the coordination of both AI and traditional software engineering techniques, including frameworks, infrastructure and security-as-code‚Ä¶ but it will come.

We placed a bet 10 years ago that everything would be computer.

Next.js started out as a server-side rendering framework, introduced incremental page generation, and doubled down on personalizing the web. At the time, the dogma was that servers weren‚Äôt needed. You were supposed to make everything static.

First we set out to prove that computers in the cloud, or servers, didn‚Äôt have to be *hard* for developers. With Vercel Functions, we made scaling compute in the cloud easy, fast, and zero configuration.

Now we‚Äôre proving compute can be cost-efficient, especially for AI workloads. Since launching https://t.co/Mfqozf4JBi 5 weeks ago, we‚Äôve seen 68% of our invocations seamlessly adopt our new compute paradigm of ‚Äúserverless servers‚Äù. Customers are seeing up to 85% cost savings ü•π.

I‚Äôm extremely excited about what‚Äôs coming next. Our computers, from our dev servers, to our build infrastructure, to our functions, will increasingly be in the hands of Agents, rather than humans alone. I anticipate the vast majority of @vercel deployments will soon be made by an agent of some kind, like @v0 or @windsurf_ai and @cursor_ai.

I can‚Äôt wait to see the next wave of applications we *all* ship on top of these foundations.

Prediction: software development will closely resemble the evolution of self-driving cars. 

- Considered for many years intractable, now run of the mill for a large subset of rides (robotaxi), all mobility within sight.

- The key metric to watch is disengagement rate (i.e.: how frequently the human operator needs total take over coding :: driving). 

- Occasional human takeover and steering still needed (remote takeover) to get the program ‚Äúunstuck‚Äù or figure out dilemmas. 

- Success is predicated on the successful interoperability with the existing environment and tools (existing programming languages, runtimes, frameworks :: streets, signs, pedestrians), rather than resetting the landscape.

Example of @wolfram_alpha being chosen by the agent: "give me 50 digits of pi" https://t.co/OgamjTfD5Q https://t.co/N3OzSKkkXj

The @vercel fluid √ó @upstash agents framework just solved one of the trickiest issues in chatbots/agents and one of my biggest pet peeves üòÜ

Notice that right after submitting my message, it immediately assigns an uuid (`/wfr_KgW5x‚Ä¶`) to the job. At this point, my internet might flake out, I might shut my laptop lid, I might go to my phone and open the chat from there‚Ä¶

What you're looking at is a resumable, durable agentic workflow that's fault tolerant on the server and on the client. On the server side, Fluid functions on @vercel will be invoked for each step, and they can fail and get retried. On the client, polling for changes ensures eventual consistency even in the presence of very long network partitions.

Shoutout to @yemreoz for collaborating with me on shipping these improvements. Check out the OSS @nextjs repo to learn these patterns and the demo at: https://t.co/ZUJCJhs1Br

ps: it's actually impressive what a wide range of questions this simple demo agent can answer by choosing between @exaailabs / @wikipedia / @wolframresearch

Vercel has one of the largest Next.js monorepos in the world. It's 8+ years old, has 65,000 modules, 7,800 dependencies, 70 active committers in Feb.

@realshcallaway I would argue local-first is a very aggressive form of prefetching (which is why these apps usually have a very large cold-start penalty). The rule above stays: you have to have a backend fast and scalable enough to seed the data quickly and to propagate the deltas.

It‚Äôs impossible to create a fast frontend without a fast backend.

Some notable exceptions that help accelerate a frontend *in spite* of a slow or resource constrained backend:

‚Ä¢ ISR. The simplest explanation of ISR is that it‚Äôs a view materialization in db lingo. The inputs to that view can be slow or even partially unavailable. But once the materialization is done by the Vercel infra, it becomes *our* problem not yours. We can globally persist it, synchronize it and virtually deliver it at the speed of light

‚Ä¢ Partial Pre-rendering. Related to ISR, but even for a highly dynamic view, we can extract the static or semi-static (think: CMS content) parts of the page and ensure their globally availability. Even if the dynamic holes of the page are slow, we flush instantly from the CDN edge, and concurrently begin to initialize dynamic resources. While the client starts to load the static <head> including critical CSS, we‚Äôre parallelizing the dynamic timeline. Game changing 

‚Ä¢ Pre-fetching. I‚Äôve called this ‚Äúnegative latency‚Äù in the past. PPR and static ISR pages can be automatically prefetched based on viewport and intent signals. Next.js also lets you easily prefetch dynamic content. These techniques give highly complex pages with lots of dynamic data the feeling of an app that‚Äôs downloaded all its data locally ahead of time. It also solves for the false dichotomy of SPA vs SSR. Transitions and clicks feel instant, but you now have the ability to avoid waterfalls and get the dynamic data faster.

Overall, you‚Äôll always have to worry about your data backends being fast. Next.js has been investing heavily in observability out of the box to this end (OpenTelemetry). I‚Äôm also a huge fan of the @vercel Observability feature that automatically captures metrics for outgoing HTTP destinations (as an aside, a phenomenal side effect of the ecosystem standardizing on `fetch`). Vendors like headless CMS, BaaS and e-commerce providers need to be held accountable to their APIs p99s and error rates, Vercel‚Äôs shields and caches non-withstanding üòä

Fundamentally, Next.js has always been an API framework. 

A core design tenet is that once an app is first loaded, subsequent navigations should be ‚Äúsoft‚Äù and snappy, to avoid restarting everything.

When `getServerSideProps` and `getStaticProps` were introduced, we ensured a special ‚ÄúAPI endpoint‚Äù was produced behind the scenes to serve a .json representation of the page. That‚Äôs what‚Äôs fetched when you use <Link> and that makes Next pages fast.

[As interesting trivia, the process of extracting the code to produce that server function was super non-trivial (i.e.: ‚Äúdead code elimination‚Äù). We produced a not super well-known tool at the time so you could visualize this (https://t.co/8T9e6WBUHq), but in the end it was altogether quite hacky and you can get an idea of why ‚Äúuse server‚Äù and ‚Äúuse client‚Äù are such a great evolution.]

gSSP was in many ways poor man‚Äôs React Server Components, but the fate was sealed that @nextjs would be a full stack framework. With RSC DX and caching improvements well underway, we can start to turn our attention to other core pieces of the backend side of Next. 

We‚Äôre shipping improvements to Middleware (with @nodejs being supported experimentally in 15.2), and we‚Äôll be investing in even better support for defining APIs via Route Handlers, starting with better documentation and a way to start an API-only project:

$ npx create-next-app@latest --api
‚ú® enhance

Part of the success of AI for code generation is explained by the fact that LLMs are indisputably great at it.

But it's also that the best way to build great products is to be your own customer. We're still in the early innings of the intelligence age, and the few people who understand AI deeply are engineers, who are highly motivated to scratch their own itches, and get their friends onboard.

If anything, this makes me even more bullish about what AI will do to other fields of human endeavor.

A neat thing about @nextjs is that you can totally use it in its simplest mode, a static page or SPA.

But it‚Äôs likely you‚Äôll eventually need more, which is what many, the @reactjs team at @meta specially, figured out over time.

And if/when you need that extra power, the tools are there, waiting for you. No need to rewrite or start your project over. Whether it‚Äôs a Route Handler (API endpoint), streaming data from the server to client (`use`), or full on server side rendering and streaming. Or a combination of these things.

Our recent improvements to defaults and how caching works (‚Äúuse cache‚Äù) are in the service of the ‚Äòprogressive disclosure‚Äô of this sophistication. Not every project will grow to that level of complexity, and that‚Äôs fine, because the platform scales with you.

Anecdotally, what I‚Äôve found so far is that most Next.js projects end up in a hybrid state. https://t.co/CzVegAMfnq, https://t.co/y2vORgcqrX and https://t.co/4h5BByoYoH mostly present as a SPA. But: v0 Community is like an e-commerce website and we heavily optimize for SEO, while the chat and preview are like a native app.

Even in the realm of e-commerce, like https://t.co/C2q4ESzL6K where we make heavy use of on-demand ISR, some pages are fully personalized and never cached, like your orders page. And every single page has a dynamically streamed ‚Äúhole‚Äù for the cart state and user auth.

tl;DR: don‚Äôt feel pressured to use every feature. Next mirrors React insofar it can start simple and grow into powering very ambitious things. The focus over recent releases has been to focus on simplicity and stability to match that progression.

Took a peek at how @grok DeepSearch is implemented, it's very neat.

One thing that stood out to me is that it's resilient to aborting the stream half-way and refreshing the page. Most chatbots struggle with this.

When they initially render the conversation, it detects whether the response is in-flight. If it's in-flight, there's a dedicated endpoint (`/rest/app-chat/conversations/reconnect-response/`) that can handle the resumption of streaming updates.

They use NDJSON (newline delimited JSON) and a simple streaming parser with async generators. Frequent updates are batched together for perf reasons.

Overall this is one of my favorite @nextjs App Router implementations to date and it raises the bar in terms of performance, reliability and design. Helping other people solve this 'resumption' problem has been high on my list (as far back as when I designed https://t.co/v6M4VQNaw0), and I'm impressed @xai shipped a solution this early on.

(Note: this is all from a quick cursory read of the client JS bundles and network activity)

There's an interesting metaphor between the personal computing era and the personal software era.

Personal computing was about decentralizing the power to use software. Thanks to AI, personal software is about the decentralization of its creation and distribution.

In the case of PCs, I'd argue that the "home computer" aspect of "personal" was significant, but lesser than the impact to businesses and enterprises. After all, the true personal computer ended up being the mobile phone.

Prior to PCs, business users were massively bottlenecked in accessing software and information. The computing scarcity was such that "timesharing" was invented so that multiple users could use the same costly mainframe machine.

If you look at software development at companies, you see the same bottleneck. Instead of "timesharing" a computer, you're time-sharing the limited and overwhelmed software development teams. Developer time is precious. It's hard to recruit, hire, onboard, and train, but crucially, it's hard to get them to *understand the business*.

Piles and piles of software have been invented to 'sort out' that bottleneck, with TODO lists and Kanban boards, and cults like agile and scrum or whatever. A lot of jobs have even been invented to act as a "translation layer" between the technical mind and the business mind.

Personal software will forever break this dichotomy. With tools like @v0, any person in the org chart can start building. They will build with the same infrastructure and components as the Real Engineers‚Ñ¢. They will deploy to the same robust and scalable cloud infrastructure.

History rhymes but seldom repeats exactly. The PC revolution had Moore's law tailwinds that led to faster computation, but the personal software era has AI scaling law tailwinds that lead to superintelligence. Eventually software will be self-writing, self-improving, and not just personal but personalized to us. As the paradigm shifts, we'll have to optimize for truth-seeking, open, and freedom-optimizing AI that's best aligned with our personal goals and interests.

This is a highly interactive app experience, not a ‚Äúwebsite‚Äù. And yet, it got faster because:

- The first hop comes back with the Partial Pre-render, rather than a blank page and a JS bundle

- This translates into really fast ‚Äútime to focused input‚Äù, which is a vital metric for any search engine or AI chatbot

- If you share a URL to a search, we stream data back in that first same hop, rather than waiting until the client loads JS, hydrates, and fetches

This brings the edge worker / runtime chapter for Vercel to a close.

The lessons:
‚óÜ Developers want full, open runtimes. A cloud runtime that promises efficiencies and has DX and ecosystems tradeoffs ain't it. We brought the compute efficiencies and cold start improvements to the existing ecosystem instead, and that's Fluid.

‚óÜ "Edge" is for routing, static assets, and prerenders‚Ä¶ not for apps, APIs & databases. Fluid is multi-region, optimizing for running your app next to your Postgres, as God through the laws of physics intended. But multi-region is not dozens or hundreds of CDN edges. Google Spanner, Turso, and Amazon DSQL are leading the charge here in helping you go global in an economical and actually performant way.

‚óÜ It's over for v8 Isolates as a cloud primitive. If we can bring I/O efficiency to microVMs with broad runtime support, the huge security tradeoff in using *the JS engine* as your virtualization layer becomes‚Ä¶ a strange value proposition to say the least üòµ‚Äçüí´

In fact, as of last week, all Edge Middleware runs on Fluid in the Vercel cloud. As I've shared[1], it's actually even faster and more efficient than before (and runtime agnostic, with @nodejs coming soon to @nextjs), while also being more secure.

@biiishal Don't want to pick on vendors, it's more so the architecture  that's broken. 

Modern hyperscalers like AWS (in tandem with Vercel) already have a massive network infrastructure footprint, so it makes putting something in front 100% redundant. Slower, less available, less secure.

This week, a large multinational retail customer of Vercel got rid of the redundant CDN vendor in front of us.

The result: major cost savings *and* performance improvements. ~150ms TTFB reductions as measured by field data, which is what their customers experience and what Google ranks them on.

These vendors tend to boast their number of PoPs (points of presence), increased performance, and DDoS mitigation capabilities. In practice, we've found that their marketing does not match reality whatsoever.

Excited to power a more secure, dynamic and generative web for everyone, by default. I look forward to sharing more stories and data from the field over coming weeks and months!

The three chapters of the web
1Ô∏è‚É£ Static
2Ô∏è‚É£ Dynamic 
3Ô∏è‚É£ Generative     ‚Üí you are here

The past 10 years were about upgrading the web from static documents and CDN cached content, to a dynamic medium

In that context Next.js flourished, static frameworks fell out of style, and React came a server-driven UI framework.

The future is generative. Less and less we will depend on Software 1.0 rendering instructions. UI will flow as a function of context and prompts and according to the user needs.

Only a handful of companies have been able to historically leverage the web medium like this, most notably Google. Now everybody can cook.

@IamNotOC @perplexity_ai The "optimization" part will largely go away. Truth-seeking AIs will be able to give quality answers regardless of 'backlinks' and <meta>

They'll find "alpha" for us by identifying products / technologies / brands that are worth of 'floating to the top' even if not widely known

Misconception: SEO doesn't matter anymore, we're all going to answer engines like @perplexity_ai.

Reality: answer engines and agents search the web to be up to date, and the motivation to rank high in *those* search results is still there.

BUT things are changing as Google continues to get "unbundled":
‚óæÔ∏é Answer engines are not going to (exclusively) use Google Search. @grok notably [pictured below] merges in a first-party feed of @x posts.
‚óæÔ∏é Large clusters of queries are going to expert, in-situ AI products like @v0 and @cursor_ai. The search is not being made, because v0 can go straight to the sources that it's highly optimized for (and cutting out SEO spam like w3schools!)
‚óæÔ∏é The crawling, indexing, and source curation infrastructure is rapidly decentralizing. @exaailabs produces curated "websets" for expert AI systems to consume. It's very likely agents will prefer to query these than performing 'generic' web searches.
‚óæÔ∏é As a website or product owner, while you previously mostly had to use one thing to understand your SEO health (Google Search Console / Webmaster Tools), now you have to worry about what the large AI chatbots say about you and your brand. This is not limited to search results, but also what the LLM overall "thinks" about you. Products like @tryprofound are looking to help you scale this monitoring.

@iamsahaj_xyz Per the metaphor, if your friend is asking to get started with Linux, odds are 99% they actually want GNU/Linux and a distribution. It's a tricky balance to find: some people go to `https://t.co/bNTCaFGztb` looking to "compile the kernel", but most people just want an OS
@ddaalee i hope not ü§£

React has become the 'linux kernel' of modern software development. The industry has broadly standardized around its 'syscall interface', from vendors shipping hooks or components as their SDKs, to LLMs being trained to generate it.

The metaphor holds further. Today, Linux is mostly used in the form of distributions that bundle it. Most users are oblivious to what kernel version they're even running, because they're interested in a working operating system with all the necessary tools to be productive, as well as an app ecosystem, support, and security patches.

A lot of people start using React by (sometimes unknowingly) assembling their own 'distributions' aka frameworks. This is akin to checking out the Linux source, running `make vmlinux`, then re-assembling the operating system by hand. I think this is a very cool thing to learn and do, and early in my career I'm very thankful I bootstrapped my own Linux systems with projects like LFS and Gentoo. It built character üòÜ and foundational knowledge.

If you're building a product or a company, I strongly recommend you pick a distribution, not assemble one. Next.js is the most popular, but naturally many others have emerged: TanStack, Remix, Astro, Waku to name a few great ones, built by passionate, expert "kernel" engineers.

Just had an incredibly illuminating conversation with @pontusab about how he's building @middayai and @languine_ai on Vercel.

Example: Midday has 150+ @nextjs Server Actions already. In his previous life, this would have been a soul-wrenching microservice fleet ü•¥. Even a separate REST API would massively degrade his iteration velocity.

It takes a village: lots of products are making this single-engineer feat of supporting the backend of 10,000+ businesses possible: @supabase, @triggerdotdev, @tursodatabase, @aisdk. 

He also gets frequent attacks, and our built-in security features and support for rate-limiting has saved the day on more than one occasion. Another tidbit is that using Turbopack for Languine has been night-and-day for DX.

I hope his journey inspires others. Go check out his products & open source contributions!
